General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

The treatment of Cr6+ waste at the Industrial Wastewater Treatment Plant (IWTP) is subject to the RMP Program Level 3 requirements because there are public receptors within the distance to the endpoint for a worst-case release and the project is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals regulations (29 CFR 1910.119). The WVA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program is process specific to address SO2 use at the IWTP, and is tailored to assure compliance under both the RMP and PSM regulations.  As part of the OSHA requirements, WVA maintains a PSM plan.

Process Safety Information: 
WVA maintains records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all covered processes.

Process Hazard Analysis: 
WVA's Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) details requirements for conducting both initial and updated PHAs in a manner compliant with 29 CFR Part 1910.119(e). All critical safety actions prompted by PHA recommendations are required to be completed prior to process startup, and non-critical items are required to be completed within the timeframe established by the PHA. The required PHA revalidation frequency is specified as at least every five years after completion of the initial PHA to ensure consistency with the as-built design.

Operating Procedures: 
All operating procedures are available to all employees through the central, electronic files in the WVA SharePoint, and the operators are routinely retrained on these procedures. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at Watervliet Arsenal:

The US Army Watervliet Arsenal (WVA) maintains an accidental release prevention program covering design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, management of change, and employee training associated with the facility's processes. Policy is provided in US Army Regulation 200-1, Environmental Protection and Enhancement and WVA's Environmental Management System Policy established by the WVA Commander. WVA maintains an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that applies to all types of emergencies, including emergencies related to the RMP Rule (40 CFR Part 68).

WVA has 24/7 on-site security and fire services including its own spill hotline. WVA also coordinates emergency response planning with local Police and Fire Departments, including Emergency Medical Services.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled at WVA:

WVA is a government-owned, government-operated facility located in Watervliet, New York, adjacent to the Hudson River 3.5 miles northeast of the City of Albany. WVA is owned by the US Department of the Army, and has been in continuous operation since 1813. WVA manufactures field artillery components (e.g., cannons) using the latest metals machining and metals processing technologies. 

Wastewater generated from the WVA manufacturing process is treated at WVA to reduce hexavalent chromium (Cr6+) to trivalent chromium (Cr3+) and the treatment process requires more than the threshold quantity of anhydrous sulfur dioxide (SO2),which is a RMP-regulated substance. Therefore, WVA is subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68, Subpart G: Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, Risk Management Plan.

WVA's operating procedures also include information on the operating limits of each process, inclusive of the consequences of deviation from these limits and the steps required to correct or avoid deviation. Procedures are subjected to a regular review and recertification to assure that the contained information is correct and up-to-date.

Training: 
The WVA section of the Army's Total Employee Development (TED) system is where personnel training is managed and also serves as the central repository for the maintenance of training records for WVA personnel. Each employee involved in the operation of any process at WVA is trained on the applicable Operating Procedures. All training includes emphasis of the specific safety and health hazards associated with the equipment and chemicals involved, as well as emergency operation and safe work practices. Initial training for each operator consists of reading the procedure, and being instructed firsthand on process operations via a walkthrough with the procedure in-hand. Upon any procedure change, each operator is retrained using the same methods as for initial training. The Training Department maintains a database of each employee's required training, including the date of the initial training, the date of the most recent training, and the date that the next refresher training is required.

Mechanical Integrity: 
WVA has established written procedures to ensure the ongoing integrity of process equipment and employees are trained in conducing these maintenance activities. Additionally, the facility has an overarching Maintenance Plan which documents the Preventative Maintenance and Inspection System. The aspects of this plan satisfy the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.73 for addressing the ongoing mechanical integrity of pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.

Contractors: 
All contractors, subcontractors and tenants at WVA are required to read and certify by signature that they understand and will abide by the rules identified in the WVA Safety Program 385-1. They must also provide copies of Safety Data Sheets (SDS) to the WVA Safety Office, submit a site safety plan and documentation of employee training.

Compliance Audits: 
The Chief of Public Works or his designee is responsible for initiating, conducting, and documenting the RMP Compliance Audits on a minimum of a three-year cycle. Any identified deficiencies are documented in the associated report,along with tracking-to-resolution the proposed corrective action(s).


Five-Year Accident History:

There have been no accidents that are required to be included in accident history over the past five years for the RMP process.


Emergency Response Program:

WVA maintains an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that is implemented as needed and used for drills internally and with outside emergency responders. The ERP addresses all types of emergencies and
fulfills plans and procedures which satisfy the emergency response requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.95 and were developed to be protective of human health and the environment. As part of the ERP, the Disaster Control Plan describes procedures, event communication and personnel responsibilities in the event of a disaster, as WVA recognizes that the potential for a chemical release exists as the result of an external event such as severe weather or an act of terrorism. WVA also maintains a WVA Fire Prevention Plan and Hazardous Material Response Plan.

nt of Change: 
The WVA Safety Manager implements the Management of Change (MOC) Procedure when the need for a change in the IWTP chromium reduction process is identified. The overall (MOC) framework at WVA ensures applicable requirements of the RMP regulations, a variety of occupational safety and health requirements, and international standards are met. The MOC Procedure begins with completion of the MOC Form, followed by a PHA. The next steps include subsequent reviews, documented and certified changes, and the process ends with updating system records and training, and the performance of a pre-startup process review.

Pre-startup Process Reviews: 
The Safety Manager, WVA Fire Chief, Industrial Hygienist, Chief of Public Works, and the Plant Leader are responsible for conducting pre-startup process reviews of the IWTP chromium reduction process after a change has been made.

Incident Investigation: 
WVA's Safety Incident Reporting & Investigation Requirements describe the reporting and investigation requirements for events involving explosions, motor vehicle incidents, severe storm or weather damage and spills with occupational injuries. Per this written procedure, the investigation team must be formed and the investigation started as soon as possible based on the class of the incident and the conditions surrounding the incident and affected area. WVA's Incident Investigation Process complies with Army Regulation 385-40, which requires formal reporting to higher headquarters for serious incidents.

Spill Reports: 
All spills at WVA are required to be reported and investigated as environmental events, even if the event is a nominal release entirely contained within secondary containment and without resulting in any health or safety impacts. Investigation of even minor events and near-misses is considered a means of identifying and addressing potential issues, and thereby preventing more significant events.
